content.webTitle: Tips, links and suggestions: what are you reading this week?

fields.headline: Tips, links and suggestions: what are you reading this week?
fields.bodyText: Welcome to this week’s blogpost. Here’s our roundup of your comments and photos from last week. Let’s start with a success story. “I’ve just finished Memento Mori by Muriel Spark,” says ignicapilla, “yet another recommendation from this forum and another that I’ve enjoyed enormously”: The thing that struck me most about the book was that the average age of the main characters is around 80 and I can’t remember reading anything else that gives more than scant attention to a single character from that age group. It’s only my second Muriel Spark novel (no prizes for guessing the other) but it certainly won’t be the last. Constellations by Sinead Gleeson has given captainlego plenty to think about: This is part memoir, part essay collection with the unifying theme of the body, and what it is like, or what it means to live our lives through our bodies (if that makes sense). Gleeson has/had a history of quite serious illness, so the book is a reflection of her experiences in dealing with her own illnesses and at the hands of various surgeons, nurses, midwives and the Irish medical profession in general. It’s a thoughtful and reflective read; at times funny, poetic and heartbreaking, but shot through with great humanity and good humour. Olga Tokarczuk’s Flights (translated by Jennifer Croft) has also had JayZed looking at constellations: Flights is a fragmentary, essayistic meditation on travel, connectedness and human anatomy with no clear narrative structure. It comprises over 100 sections ranging from a couple of sentences to 30+ pages: while some of the longer sections can be read as short stories, many of the shorter sections are simply brief meditations on an aspect of travel psychology or anatomy. Tokarczuk has described this structure as a “constellation novel” in which the author throws her stories into orbit, allowing the reader to form meaningful shapes from them. It makes for a challenging read, and I have to confess to finishing the novel (if indeed it is a novel) feeling that I’d encountered some interesting themes and ideas among the fragments, but I hadn’t quite figured out what the point was. Despite that, there was a lot to like about this. The writing is consistently good, and the book included some compelling stories (the Dutch anatomist who dissected his own amputated leg; a Polish man whose family inexplicably goes missing on a Croatian island; a retired sailor who takes a ferry out into the open seas) and explored many interesting ideas. I felt that I learned a lot from the journey, even if the destination wasn’t clear to me. Maybe that was the point. Elizabeth Strout’s Olive Kitteridge has enchanted allworthy: How could I have not read it before? Strout’s an alchemist. How does she do it? You think you know someone and then you’re shown again. So deft with just a few brush strokes and Olive herself. How brilliant is it to have a no frills, no nonsense, complex heroine who is flawed and yet we care for her. It is pure magic. Julia Boyd’s Travellers in the Third Reich has fascinated Alexia_R: I think I may have first heard about this book here. If so, thank you to those of you who recommended it. I thought it was a fantastic piece of research. Utterly fascinating. She draws on material from all sorts of People travelling in Germany in the 1920s and 1930s, naturally many of them are well-off but by no means all. Highly recommended to anyone with an interest in Germany and also just in the rise of extremism and how people actually living through it see it without the benefit of hindsight. Purity is Veufveuve’s first time with a Jonathan Franzen novel: I thought it was just terrific storytelling. He controls the multiple strands superbly as they weave across time and space, bringing it together beautifully at the end. (The nod to Dickens via Pip is cheeky but not entirely unearned.) My wife says I’m the only person she can admit to having enjoyed this to. There’s little doubt its written with a powerful male gaze but I also think the only two truly sympathetic characters are both women: Pip and Leila. Finally, NicolaVintageReads has been re-reading Persuasion and – oh my goodness: My edition has the cancelled chapter where Captain Wentworth proposes to Anne at the lodgings of Admiral Croft. Would be wonderful to know why Austen changed her mind about this chapter and decided on Captain Wentworth declaring his feelings in a letter written while Anne was in the room. The more I re-read Persuasion the more I like the cancelled chapter! That’s right. There’s an alternate (almost) ending. Wow. Interesting links about books and reading John F Callahan looks at decades of Ralph Ellison correspondence. The secret feminist history of Shakespeare and Company. Critics from the New York Times discuss their favourite books of the year. Bharat Tandon tries to make Henry James’s Bostonians sound interesting. “Printers ink is the greater explosive,” reads a sign watching over the Poetry Room at City Lights Bookstore. An encomium to a special place. He needs a bigger boat: Connor Harrison wants to get his books to Canada. If you’re on Instagram, now you can share your reads with us: simply tag your posts with the hashtag #GuardianBooks, and we’ll include a selection in this blog. Happy reading!
